Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Diffusion of Democratic Norms: Examining How Democracy INGO Strategies Contribute to Hybrid Regimes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: As a governmental system, democracy produces an environment where fundamental freedoms are respected and fulfilled, and promotes both peace and prosperity, as well as individual well-being. In pursuit of these ends, democracy aid is dispensed by various actors including democracy-promoting international non-governmental organizations (DINGOs). Such aid has skyrocketed, with 2008 global expenditures nearing $20 billion. Yet the success of this endeavor remains unclear because at the same time, hybrid regimes – governments that co-opt democratic institutions and policies to mask authoritarian practices – are proliferating. Moreover, aid is often ineffective, and typical aid strategies can incentivize superficial democratization while legitimizing and reinforcing nondemocratic rule. Thus, DINGOs themselves may contribute to hybrid growth. However, the role of DINGOs and their strategies regarding hybrids and democratization is underexplored. This project empirically examines how nations’ ties to DINGOs impact their level of democracy in policy and practice, as well as how various types of DINGO aid strategies improve or reduce DINGO effectiveness in promoting democracy. As such, the project assesses how democracy aid influences hybrid regimes. By identifying factors relevant for democracy promotion, this project will help various actors such as nonprofits and governments safeguard human rights and improve citizen well-being worldwide. <br/> <br/>This project combines statistical and computational methodologies to examine DINGOs’ impact on democratic policies and practices cross-nationally in five-year intervals from 1980 to 2015. It uses content analysis of the Yearbook of International Organizations to count nations’ annual DINGO ties for each selected year. It then employs random effects regression to understand how those ties impact democracy in policy and in practice cross-nationally and longitudinally, using a novel measure of democracy. It further investigates this relationship by analyzing 30 DINGOs’ annual reports using one type of automated content analysis, Latent Dirichlet Application (LDA) topic modeling, to quantify which strategies DINGOs pursue, and to what degree. Finally, it draws upon these data to analyze how DINGO impact on democracy varies by DINGO strategy cross-nationally and over time using random effects regression. This design thus makes it possible to examine and compare, for the first time, the direct effects of DINGOs on democracy in policy and in practice, and how aid strategy modifies this relationship. Findings will inform sociological theories regarding democracy promotion and comparative governmental organization.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Democracy is in crisis. Despite the continued efforts of hundreds of democracy-promoting international non-governmental organizations (DINGOs) over 60 nations exhibited democratic decline in 2021 alone. This project investigated democracy promotion's role in this process.

 Specifically, it evaluated how democracy promoting INGOs (DINGOs) help and hinder the diffusion of democratic norms to nations' policies, practices, and the discord between the two (or decoupling) from 1981-2015. Engaging with theories of world society and democracy, this study used a combination of network and longitudinal fixed effects methodologies to analyze how nations' ties to DINGOs and their centrality within DINGO networks impacts outcomes related to suffrage and civil liberties. Results suggest that DINGO efficacy varies greatly by component of democracy and world system position. On one hand, DINGOs are negatively associated with suffrage and are unable to hold states accountable to their promises. These effects are exacerbated when democracy aid is high. Although DINGO networks also contribute to civil liberties decoupling in low-income nations, they do improve democracy and reduce decoupling in well-funded, middle-income nations. Thus, under certain circumstances, DINGOs can advance global aims to improve democracy.

These results offer several contributions to the literature. Methodologically, this project offers up a new dataset documenting DINGO aims, activities, and linkages to nations over time - thus enabling future research related to global non-state democracy promotion. Substantively, it expands on existing work highlighting the external predictors of democratization. By giving adequate attention to the impact of non-state actors and organizations on this process, it offers new insight to a robust body of work which, up to this point, has emphasizes the impact of democracy- promoting statist institutions. In merging the literatures on democracy and world society, this project also incorporates the ongoing examination of hybrid regimes into an existing theoretical framework of norm diffusion. In doing so, it enables a greater understanding of how global normative influences shape the diffusion of democracy at several levels of compliance while providing one new way to think about and measure hybrid regimes.

At the same time, by integrating the world society and world systems frameworks, this study demonstrates the importance of considering how conventional issues of power and privilege between states impact the diffusion process. It also introduces a new perspective for thinking about how and why nations decouple in response to calls for compliance. Finally, by examining the moderating role of democracy aid, this study more clearly distinguishes between the effects of different types of democracy assistance, thus providing a more nuanced understanding of the myriad of ways democracy promotion shapes democracy. 

The broader impacts of this study must also be considered. What are the real-world consequences of DINGO effects? Certainly, DINGOs comprise only a mere portion of global democracy promotion efforts. Even so, they appear to have a significant (and not altogether positive) effect. In addition to DINGOs' obvious capacity to influence the rights, freedom, and justice of people around the world and the implications for prosperity these effects have, it is also worth considering these trends in the context of the broader global moment. 

For the first time since the inception of the institution of global democracy promotion, the US is no longer the global hegemon. What does this mean for the sustainability of democracy promotion efforts? Although the effects of US democratization efforts have been underwhelming at best, US primacy upheld the liberal international order. With this order now in flux, illiberalism has rampantly spread, even among longevous democracies. Consequently, now, more than ever, it is crucial that we ensure DINGOs are positive contributing to democracy, and not unintentionally reinforcing illiberalism. 

DINGOs may be of particular need during this period of liberal precarity. Who, if not citizens, will continue to advocate for democratic rights? Coercion exerted by nation-states or statist institutions intended to foster democracy only works when those nations in power agree democracy is necessary. As the world shifts away from liberal unipolarity towards more multipolar, illiberal ways of acting, it may not always be so that the nations making the rules of the game prioritize democratic government. DINGOs, who are allegiant to citizens - not states - may be an especially crucial line of defense against authoritarianism in the coming era. Thus, this work offers insights about how global actors can best address the ongoing global democracy crisis.
